title: 115_s2495
content: The Act is known as the "Student, Teachers, and Officers Preventing School Violence Act of 2018" or the "STOP School Violence Act of 2018." It includes a grant program for school security. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to provide evidence-based training, technology, and equipment to prevent violence in schools. This includes training to prevent student violence against others and self, as part of the STOP School Violence Act of 2018. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to provide evidence-based technology and equipment for school security and violence prevention, including anonymous reporting systems for threats of school violence. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include evidence-based school threat assessment and equip school personnel with technology for violence prevention. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to allow states, local governments, and Indian tribes to use grants for contracting with schools, nonprofit organizations, or local government entities for authorized purposes. The amendment also increases the grant allocation to 75 percent and removes a specific paragraph. Additionally, the Director must ensure certain criteria are met when awarding grants under this part. The Director must ensure an equitable distribution of funds among schools for improvements and specify the process for identifying evidence-based programs under the grant. In subparagraph (B), changes are made to include "other relevant individuals" and replace "child psychologists" with "licensed mental health professionals" in paragraph (2). The applicant must maintain and report data as required by the Director, certify that funded programs meet all requirements, provide correct information, and comply with all provisions. The applicant must comply with all provisions of the STOP School Violence Act of 2018 and grant accountability requirements for grants awarded by the Director under this part. The STOP School Violence Act of 2018 requires compliance with grant accountability requirements for grants awarded by the Director under this part, including definitions and amendments to specific sections. The STOP School Violence Act of 2018 defines 'evidence-based' as a program, practice, technology, or equipment that shows a significant effect on outcomes based on strong, moderate, or promising evidence from well-designed studies. The STOP School Violence Act of 2018 defines 'evidence-based' as a program, practice, technology, or equipment that demonstrates positive outcomes and aligns with best practices for school security. The STOP School Violence Act of 2018 establishes public commissions and task forces to make recommendations for school security, ensuring compliance with applicable codes. It also defines 'tribal organization' and allocates funding for fiscal year 2018. The STOP School Violence Act of 2018 allocates funding for school safety initiatives, with $75,000,000 for fiscal year 2018 and $100,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2019 to 2028. Funds can be offset by reducing appropriations for the Comprehensive School Safety Initiative. The Act prohibits the use of funds for firearms or firearms training but does not restrict other laws from permitting such activities.
